'''AES67''' is a [[technical standard]] for [[audio over IP]] and [[audio over ethernet]] interoperability. The standard was developed by the [[Audio Engineering Society]] and first published in September 2013. It is a [[layer 3]] protocol suite based on existing [[Technical standard|standards]] and is designed to allow interoperability between various IP-based audio networking systems such as [[Ravenna (networking)|RAVENNA]], [[Livewire (networking)|Livewire]], [[Q-LAN]] and [[Dante (networking)|Dante]]. It also provides interoperability with layer 2 technologies, like [[Audio Video Bridging|Audio Video Bridging (AVB)]].<ref name=infocomm2016/>
AES67 promises interoperability between previously competing networked audio systems<ref name=Harvey/> and long-term network interoperation between systems.<ref name=Installation/> Since its publication, AES67 has been implemented independently by several manufacturers and adopted by many others.
==Development== The standard was developed by the [[Audio Engineering Society]] beginning at the end of 2010.<ref name=aesinit/> The standard was initially published September 2013.<ref name=infocomm/><ref name=svg/><ref name=prosoundweb/><ref name=radio/> A second printing including a patent statement from [[Audinate]] was published in March 2014. An update including clarifications and error corrections was issued in September 2015.<ref name=aessc/>
The Media Networking Alliance was formed in October 2014 to promote adoption of AES67.<ref name="RadioWorld MNA"/>
In October 2014 a [[plugfest]] was held to test interoperability achieved with AES67.<ref name=psnplugfest/><ref name=aespf2014/> A second plugfest was conducted in November 2015<ref name=aespf2015/> and third in February 2017.<ref name="aespf2017"/>
In May 2016, the AES published a report describing synchronization interoperability between AES67 and [[SMPTE 2059-2]].<ref name=aesr16/>
In September 2017, [[SMPTE]] published ST 2110, a standard for [[professional video over IP]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.smpte.org/news-events/news-releases/smpte%C2%AE-approves-st-2110-standards-professional-media-over-managed-ip |title=SMPTE Approves ST 2110-30 Standards for Professional Media Over Managed IP Networks |access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> {{nowrap|ST 2110-30}} uses AES67 as the transport for audio accompanying the video.<ref>{{citation |title=Audio for Television: How AES67 and Uncompressed 2022/2110/TR03 Video Fit Together |doi=10.5594/JMI.2017.2703479 |author=Leigh Whitcomb |date=30 June 2017 |work=SMPTE Motion Imaging Journal |publisher=SMPTE}}</ref>
In December 2017 the Media Networking Alliance merged with the Alliance for IP Media Solutions (AIMS) combining efforts to promote standards-based network transport for audio and video.<ref name="RapidTV"/>
In April 2018 AES67-2018 was published. The principal change in this revision is addition of a [[protocol implementation conformance statement]] (PICS).<ref name="AES67-2018"/>
==Adoption== The standard has been implemented by [[Lawo]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lawo.com/en/up-to-date/news/nbsp/lawo_supports_successful_aes67_interoperability_demo_during_aes_convention_in_new_york.html|title=Lawo supports successful AES67 Interoperability Demo during AES Convention in New York|last=Lawo|date=|website=www.lawo.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref> [[Telos Systems|Axia]],<ref name=soundandpicture/> AMX (in SVSI devices), Wheatstone,<ref name=rwaes67/><ref name=TVT/> [https://www.extron.de/company/article.aspx?id=aes67 Extron Electronics], Riedel,<ref name="Digital Production"/> [http://coveloz.com/bach Coveloz Technologies],<ref name="coveloz-avnu-aes67" /> [[ALC NetworX]],<ref name=radioworld/> [[Audinate]],<ref>https://www.audinate.com/faq-catagories/aes67</ref><ref name=inavate/><ref name=soundforums/><ref name=proaudiocentral/><ref name=prosoundnews/><ref name=rAVe/> Archwave,<ref name=archwave/> Digigram,<ref name=iabm/> Sonifex,<ref name=sonifex/> [[Yamaha]],<ref name=YamahaPSW/> [[QSC Audio Products|QSC]],<ref name=qsc/> Neutrik, Attero Tech,<ref name=Attero/> Merging Technologies,<ref name=Merging/><ref name=MergingAudioMedia/><ref name=MergingAudioMedia2/><ref name=MergingProaudio/> Gallery SIENNA,<ref name="sienna-tv.com">http://www.sienna-tv.com/ndi/aes67.html</ref> and is supported by RAVENNA-enabled devices under its AES67 Operational Profile.<ref name=ravenna_aes67/>
==Shipping Products== Over time this table will grow to become a resource for integration and compatibility between devices. The discovery methods supported by each device are critical for integration since the AES67 specification does not stipulate how this should be done, but instead provides a variety of options or suggestions. Also, AES67 specifies Multicast or Unicast but many AES67 devices only support Multicast.

The '''AKLT model''' is an extension of the one-dimensional [[quantum mechanics|quantum]] [[Heisenberg model (quantum)|Heisenberg spin model]]. The proposal and exact solution of this model by [[Ian Affleck|Affleck]], [[Elliott H. Lieb|Lieb]], Kennedy and Tasaki<ref name="Affleck:1987" /> provided crucial insight into the physics of the spin-1 Heisenberg chain.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Haldane | first1 = F. D. M. | year = 1983 | title = Nonlinear Field Theory of Large-Spin Heisenberg Antiferromagnets: Semiclassically Quantized Solitons of the One-Dimensional Easy-Axis Néel State| url = | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 50 | issue = | page = 1153 | doi=10.1103/physrevlett.50.1153 | bibcode=1983PhRvL..50.1153H}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Haldane | first1 = F. D. M. | year = 1983 | title = Continuum dynamics of the 1-D Heisenberg antiferromagnet: Identification with the O(3) nonlinear sigma model| doi = 10.1016/0375-9601(83)90631-x | journal = Phys. Lett. A | volume = 93 | issue = | page = 464 |bibcode = 1983PhLA...93..464H }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Affleck | first1 = I. | last2 = Haldane | first2 = F. D. M. | year = 1987 | title = Critical theory of quantum spin chains| url = | journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 36 | issue = | page = 5291 | doi=10.1103/physrevb.36.5291|bibcode = 1987PhRvB..36.5291A }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Affleck | first1 = I. | year = 1989 | title = Quantum spin chains and the Haldane gap| url = | journal = J. Phys.: Condens. Matter | volume = 1 | issue = | page = 3047 | doi=10.1088/0953-8984/1/19/001|bibcode = 1989JPCM....1.3047A }}</ref> It has also served as a useful example for such concepts as valence bond solid order, [[symmetry-protected topological order]]<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gu | first1 = Zheng-Cheng | last2 = Wen | first2 = Xiao-Gang | year = 2009 | title = Tensor-Entanglement-Filtering Renormalization Approach and Symmetry-Protected Topological Order | arxiv = 0903.1069 | journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 80 | issue = | page = 155131 | doi=10.1103/physrevb.80.155131|bibcode = 2009PhRvB..80o5131G }}</ref><ref name="Pollmann:2012" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = Xie | last2 = Gu | first2 = Zheng-Cheng | last3 = Wen | first3 = Xiao-Gang | year = 2011 | title = Classification of Gapped Symmetric Phases in 1D Spin Systems | arxiv = 1008.3745 | journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 83 | issue = | page = 035107 | doi=10.1103/physrevb.83.035107 | bibcode=2011PhRvB..83c5107C}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = Xie | last2 = Liu | first2 = Zheng-Xin | last3 = Wen | first3 = Xiao-Gang | year = 2011 | title = 2D symmetry-protected topological orders and their protected gapless edge excitations | arxiv = 1106.4752 | journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 84 | issue = | page = 235141 | doi=10.1103/physrevb.84.235141 | bibcode=2011PhRvB..84w5141C}}</ref> and matrix product state wavefunctions.
== Background ==
A major motivation for the AKLT model was the [[Majumdar–Ghosh model|Majumdar–Ghosh chain]]. Because two out of every set of three neighboring spins in a Majumdar–Ghosh ground state are paired into a singlet, or valence bond, the three spins together can never be found to be in a spin 3/2 state. In fact, the Majumdar–Ghosh Hamiltonian is nothing but the sum of all projectors of three neighboring spins onto a 3/2 state.
The main insight of the AKLT paper was that this construction could be generalized to obtain exactly solvable models for spin sizes other than 1/2. Just as one end of a valence bond is a spin 1/2, the ends of two valence bonds can be combined into a spin 1, three into a spin 3/2, etc.
== Definition ==
Affleck et al. were interested in constructing a one-dimensional state with a valence bond between every pair of sites. Because this leads to two spin 1/2s for every site, the result must be the wavefunction of a spin 1 system.
For every adjacent pair of the spin 1s, two of the four constituent spin 1/2s are stuck in a total spin zero state. Therefore, each pair of spin 1s is forbidden from being in a combined spin 2 state. By writing this condition as a sum of projectors, AKLT arrived at the following Hamiltonian
: <math> \hat H = \sum_j \vec{S}_j \cdot \vec{S}_{j+1} + \frac{1}{3} (\vec{S}_j \cdot \vec{S}_{j+1})^2 </math>
This Hamiltonian is similar to the spin 1, one-dimensional [[quantum mechanics|quantum]] [[Heisenberg model (quantum)|Heisenberg spin model]] but has an additional "biquadratic" spin interaction term.
== Ground state ==
By construction, the ground state of the AKLT Hamiltonian is the valence bond solid with a single valence bond connecting every neighboring pair of sites. Pictorially, this may be represented as
[[File:AKLT GroundState.png]]
Here the solid points represent spin 1/2s which are put into singlet states. The lines connecting the spin 1/2s are the valence bonds indicating the pattern of singlets. The ovals are projection operators which "tie" together two spin 1/2s into a single spin 1, projecting out the spin 0 or singlet subspace and keeping only the spin 1 or triplet subspace. The symbols "+", "0" and "−" label the standard spin 1 basis states (eigenstates of the <math>S^z</math> operator).<ref name="Schollwoeck:2011" />
===Spin 1/2 edge states===
For the case of spins arranged in a ring (periodic boundary conditions) the AKLT construction yields a unique ground state. But for the case of an open chain, the first and last spin 1 have only a single neighbor, leaving one of their constituent spin 1/2s unpaired. As a result, the ends of the chain behave like free spin 1/2 moments even though the system consists of spin 1s only.
The spin 1/2 edge states of the AKLT chain can be observed in a few different ways. For short chains, the edge states mix into a singlet or a triplet giving either a unique ground state or a three-fold multiplet of ground states. For longer chains, the edge states decouple exponentially quickly as a function of chain length leading to a ground state manifold that is four-fold degenerate.<ref name="Kennedy:1990" /> By using a numerical method such as [[DMRG]] to measure the local magnetization along the chain, it is also possible to see the edge states directly and to show that they can be removed by placing actual spin 1/2s at the ends.<ref name="White:1993" /> It has even proved possible to detect the spin 1/2 edge states in measurements of a quasi-1D magnetic compound containing a small amount of impurities whose role is to break the chains into finite segments.<ref name="Hagiwara:1990" />
===Matrix product state representation===
The simplicity of the AKLT ground state allows it to be represented in compact form as a [[matrix product state]]. This is a wavefunction of the form
: <math>|\Psi\rangle = \sum_{\{s\}} \operatorname{Tr}[A^{s_1} A^{s_2} \ldots A^{s_N}] |s_1 s_2 \ldots s_N\rangle.</math>
Here the As are a set of three matrices labeled by <math>s_j</math> and the trace comes from assuming periodic boundary conditions.
The AKLT ground state wavefunction corresponds to the choice:<ref name="Schollwoeck:2011" />
: <math>A^{+} = +\sqrt{\tfrac{2}{3}}\ \sigma^{+} </math>
: <math>A^{0} = -\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{3}}\ \sigma^{z}</math>
: <math>A^{-} = -\sqrt{\tfrac{2}{3}}\ \sigma^{-}</math>
where <math>\sigma</math> is a [[Pauli matrix]].
== Generalizations and extensions ==
The AKLT model has been solved on lattices of higher dimension,<ref name="Affleck:1987"/><ref name="Wei:2011"/> even in [[quasicrystals]] .{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} The model has also been constructed for higher Lie algebras including [[SU(n)|SU(''n'')]],<ref name="Greiter:2007a"/><ref name="Greiter:2007b"/> [[SO(n)|SO(''n'')]],<ref name="Tu:2008"/> [[Sp(n)]] <ref name="Schuricht:2008"/> and extended to the [[quantum groups]] SUq(''n'').<ref name="SantosParaan2012"/>
